question: Question_03
statement:
There are two linear transformations of $R^2$ that map the square with
vertices at $(0,0), (1,0), (0,1), (1,1)$ to the square with vertices at
$(0,0), (1,1), (-1,1), (0,2)$. Call them $T_1$ and $T_2$. Determine the
matrices of $T_1$ and $T_2$.
sols:
As that matrices map the square to the square, it will map the corners
to the corners, thus we will see all possible ways to map the four
corners to the four new corners.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  First, linear transforms must bring the vector $(0,0)$ to the vector
  $(0,0)$. So one of the corners is taken care of already.
\item
  Next, note that there is a relation between the corners of the
  original square, that is $(1,0)+(0,1) = (1,1)$. As linear
  transformation preserve sums, \emph{T(a+b) = T(a)+T(b)}, we need to
  have the same relation in the target corners, which we do
  $(1,1) + (-1,1) = (0,2)$. Hence any linear transform between the two
  squares must send \emph{(1,1)} to \emph{(0,2)}.
\item
  Thus, we are left with sending $(0,1),(1,0)$ to $(1,1),(-1,1)$, and
  there are two ways to do so. As $(0,1),(1,0)$ forms a basis of the
  matrix, knowing where theses two vectors go also pins down the two
  matrices uniquely. We simply need to put the result in the columns of
  the transformation matrix:
\end{itemize}

$\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1  \\ 
1 & 1
\end{array} \right]$ and $\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-1 & 1  \\ 
1 & 1
\end{array} \right]$
hints:
As the matrices must map the square edges to the square edges, we need
to figure out where the four corners are mapped to. Use the fact that
\emph{T\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{T\textsubscript{2}} are linear,
which restricts your options.
